Oh man, even after a good lunch, I'm not sure that I'm up to explaining cla=
ssloader conflicts, but I'll grab a fresh cup of coffee and try. :-)

The i=
ssue all boils down to who knows what and when. I suspect that the reason t=
hat you have not had this problem on Windows is that you have most likely s=
et the CLASSPATH environment variable ahead of time and it is in the enviro=
nment when you start Ant. Ant uses the existing CLASSPATH value and adds th=
e JAR files from it's lib directory to that list. It then performs all of t=
he rest of it's work with that combined personal classpath. This would expl=
ain why it can find JUnit and why JUnit can find everything that it needs.
=

 /------------------\
 |System Classloader|
 \------------------/
        =
  |
          |
          V
 /------------------\
 | Ant Classloader  |
 \-=
-----------------/
          |
          |
          V
 /------------------=
\
 | JUnit Classloader|
 \------------------/

Now, my personal recommendat=
ion is to run with an empty CLASSPATH in your environment. This helps preve=
nt things working by accident. I either set the classpath within a script t=
hat calls my program or I build a classpath within Ant when compiling and b=
uilding. The reason that just adding the JUnit JAR file to the classpath wi=
thin Ant doesn't work (for example with the <PATH> declaration) is that you=
 are trying to add JUnit to Ant after Ant has started and already built it'=
s own classpath.

              /------------------\
              |System =
Classloader|
              \------------------/
                       |
  =
                     |
          .-------------------------.
          |   =
                      |
 /------------------\      /------------------\
 | =
Ant Classloader  |      | JUnit Classloader|
 \------------------/      \--=
----------------/

This gives you parallel classloaders, with the danger th=
at one classloader might have a different classpath than the other, as well=
 as some of the other nefarious stuff that goes on in classloaders, includi=
ng class-caching (always an opportunity for confusion).

So, the best compr=
imise between how you did things with Windows and moving to the Mac, is to =
dump classloader troublemakers like JUnit into your Ant lib directory.

All=
 that being said, I strongly recommend the Mac for development work. I clas=
s myself as a switcher: I switched from Linux to OS X (and my wife switched=
 from Windows to OS X). I love my Macs (a dual G4 desktop and an iBook for =
those get up and go moments).

I hope this helps. I know what I wanted to s=
ay, but it's a very complex subject and I've been interupted a millions tim=
es while typing this so far! ;-)

Simon
